instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to evaluate the ability of classification detailed Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) map with crop type classes and broader categories?
Output: Monthly and yearly optical features from Copernicus Sentinel-2 (S2) spectral reflectance and spectral indices, alongside decadal composites from Copernicus Sentinel-1 (S1) microwave sensor, were extracted for the EU-28 territory for 2018 using Google Earth Engine (GEE).

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the ability of classification detailed Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) map with crop type classes and broader categories and how far can this metric go in?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the ability of classification for the detailed LULC map with crop type classes and broader categories was Overall Accuracy (OA). The OA reached 82.7% when grouping the 21 classes into 8 broader categories.

instruction: How were the Copernicus Sentinel-1 (S1) and Sentinel-2 (S2) satellite data combined in ther related research to produce a detailed Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) map with crop type classes and broader categories over 28 Member States of Europe (EU-28)?
Output: In the related research, the Copernicus Sentinel-1 (S1) and Sentinel-2 (S2) satellite data were combined by extracting monthly and yearly optical features from the spectral reflectance and spectral indices of the Sentinel-2 data. Additionally, decadal composites from the Sentinel-1 microwave sensor were also extracted. These features were extracted for the EU-28 territory for the year 2018 using Google Earth Engine (GEE). Five different feature sets, consisting of a mixture of indicators, were created using these extracted features as input training data. The Random Forest (RF) machine learning algorithm was then applied to classify these feature sets, resulting in the generation of classification models. These models were compared using an identical validation dataset to evaluate their performance in producing a detailed Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) map with crop type classes and broader categories over the 28 Member States of Europe (EU-28).

instruction: Can the combination of Copernicus Sentinel-1 (S1) and Sentinel-2 (S2) satellite data be considered a superior spectral feature processing method compared to traditional methods in producing a detailed Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) map with crop type classes and broader categories over 28 Member States of Europe (EU-28)?
Output: Yes, the combination of Copernicus Sentinel-1 (S1) and Sentinel-2 (S2) satellite data can be considered a superior spectral feature processing method compared to traditional methods in producing a detailed Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) map with crop type classes and broader categories over 28 Member States of Europe (EU-28). The investigation demonstrates that by combining S1 and S2 data, a full coverage map with less dependence on cloud effects and appropriate overall accuracy (OA) can be achieved. The study shows that the combination of S1 and S2 time series can provide slightly better results and enhance spatial coverage compared to using individual S1 or S2 data.
